occurrences.line_text: And here and there were pleasant arbors pight,
Here neede you to remember, how erewhile
Yet sonnes of Neptune, now assembled here:
Onely what needeth, shall be here fulfild,
That seem'd like siluer, sprinckled here and theare
And in this prison put him here with me:
In this sad plight he walked here and there,
[here, in 1609, 'The end of the Fourth Booke.']
The instrument whereof loe here thy Artegall.
Whilest here on earth she liued mortallie.
Astrï¿½a here mongst earthly men did dwell,
Astraea loathing lenger here to space
This lucklesse Ladie, which now here doth headlesse lie.
And left me here, both his & mine owne loue to morne.
Deuided be betwixt you here in sight,
Take here your owne, that doth you best beseeme,
Within three daies (quoth hee) as I do here,
But in my way a little here beyond
And hid them selues in corners here and there;
But here and there before his presence flew,
But for so much as to my lot here lights,
True vertue to aduance, shall here recounted bee.
As for this Ladie, which he sheweth here,
And turne we here to this faire furrowes end
Then this of Artegall, which here we haue to say.
My brother here declared hath to you:
Sir Terpine, haplesse man, what make you here?
Loe here this ring, which shall thy warrant bee,
That here and there like scattred sheepe they lay.
For that Osyris, whilest he liued here,
Whereof I haue to treat here presently.
There is a mighty man, which wonnes here by
From side to side they tost him here and there,
And here and there shooting forth siluer streames,
Was brought to her sad doome, as here was to be seene.
And harbour here in safety from those rauenous dogs.
Whiles she alone is left, and thou here found?
This euill manner, which ye here maintaine,
But were he here, that would it with his sword
For not I him, as this his Ladie here
Caught her thus loosely wandring here and there,
Loe I defie thee, and here challenge make,
That here is at his gate an errant Knight,
Here they of force (as fortune now did fall)
Here by the Gods, and fed with heauenly sap,
By straunge occasion, that here needs forth be set.
Therein the Hermite, which his life here led
And you faire sonne, which here thus long now lie
What meaneth this, which here I see before?
Now here, now there, and oft him neare he mist;
Here in this bottle (sayd the sory Mayd)
In which ye father here doe dwell at ease,
This lowly quiet life, which I inherite here.
Of life, which here in lowlinesse ye lead,
I may here with your selfe some small repose obtaine.
Whose sundry parts were here too long to tell:
Here leadest in this goodly merry make,
Which here with thee doe make their pleasant playes?
In sommers shade himselfe here rested weary.
For which the Graces that here wont to dwell,
That here on earth is no sure happinesse,
First all the captiues, which they here had hent,
Then here to see all desolate and wast,
Which with those gentle shepherds here I wont to lead.
So did he fly amongst them here and there,
Through which the Monckes he chaced here & there.
And them amongst were mingled here and there,
Now praysd, hereafter deare thou shalt repent:
Into the which hereafter thou maiest happen fall.
Least thou perhaps hereafter wish, and be withstood.
Doth fall, whose like hereafter seldome may,
My Lord, my King, be nought hereat dismayd,
But Phlegeton is sonne of Herebus and Night;
But Herebus sonne of Aeternitie is hight.
Thy dwelling is, in Herebus blacke hous,
(Blacke Herebus thy husband is the foe
But if of daunger which hereby doth dwell,
Which, those his cruell foes, that stand hereby,
Let all that liue, hereby be counselled,
This day as I in solace sate hereby
Then wote you, Sir, that in this Church hereby,
Herein, as thus. It lately so befell,
Whose soueraine powre is herein most exprest,
Herein the noblesse of this knight exceedes,
That herein doest all earthly Princes pas?
Hereof this gentle knight vnweeting was,
No magicke arts hereof had any might,
Newes hereof to her other sisters came,
The roofe hereof was arched ouer head,
Tydings hereof came to his mothers eare;
To drincke hereof, whereby all cares forepast
So did those olde Heroes hereof taste,
To whom the right hereof it selfe hath sold;
Besides for recompence hereof, I shall
She in regard hereof refusde and thought vnfit.
Hereto perforce. But ï¿½ dred Soueraine
Well knowne, and far renowmed heretofore,
But you, faire Sir, be not herewith dismaid,
Yet cruell Cupid, not herewith content,
But most my Lord is grieued herewithall,
With thousand blessings she is heried;
Ne heritage of natiue soueraintie,
Enioyd an heritage of lasting peace,
Till aged Hely by dew heritage it gaynd.
The heritage of all celestiall grace.
And from the heritage, which she did clame,
To hinder thee from the iust heritage
And mother of a frutefull heritage,
In th'heritage of our vnhappie paine:
That they had beene that faire Hermaphrodite,
Weening therein some holy Hermit lay,
with th'Hermit leaues behynd.
A little lowly Hermitage it was,
And eke a litle Hermitage thereby,
By which a little Hermitage there lay,
He thence them led into his Hermitage,
He tooke him selfe vnto this Hermitage,
Wherein the Hermite dewly wont to say
Therein the Hermite, which his life here led
Whom when the Hermite present saw in place,
The Hermite heales both Squire and dame
Howbe that carefull Hermite did his best,
Of that good Hermite both they tooke their leaue,
In that good Hermits charge, whom he did pray
At an Herneshaw, that lyes aloft on wing,
And stirredst vp th'Heroes high intents,
That one of th'old Heroes seemes to bee:
And braue exploits which great Heroes wonne,
So did those olde Heroes hereof taste,
By whom those old Heroes wonne such fame;
Whilome those great Heroes got thereby
Wondrous great prowesse and heroick worth
The higher place in her Heroick mind:
And low abase the high heroicke spright,
Through his Heroicke grace, and honorable gest.
What huge heroicke magnanimity
With warlike numbers and Heroicke sound,
And inward grudge fild his heroicke brest:
Rose vp, inspired with heroicke heat,
Or surely borne of some Heroicke sead,
Stoupes at a flying heron with proud disdaine,
Strikes at an Heron with all his bodies sway,
And harts of great Hero's doest enrage,
Did much emmoue his stout heroï¿½icke heart,
And for Apolloes honor highly herried.
But Venus hers thence farre away conuayd,
Th'other in hers an hony-lady Bee;
To you that ornament of hers pertaines,
Which was not hers, as many it mistooke,
My knight hers soone, as seemes, to daunger droue
With this sad hersall of his heauy stresse,
For the faire Damzell from the holy herse
Bene they all dead, and laid in dolefull herse?
At last faire Hesperus in highest skie
Like Hesperus emongst the lesser lights,
So long that now the golden Hesperus
T'obey their riders hest, as seemed good.
But comes vnto the place, where th'Hethen knight
Me hether brought with him, as swift as wind,
But haue perforce him hether brought away.
How euer by hard hap he hether came;
Vnlesse to me thou hether bring with speed
The selfe same euening fortune hether droue,
For all that hetherto hath long delayd
Ne thenceforth feare the thing that hethertoo
Through other great aduentures hethertoo
Diuide their works, haue past through heuen sheene,
With heauenly gifts from heuen first enraced?
Shall Heuenfield be cald to all posterity.
For th'heuens the[m]selues, whence mortal men implore
Whose semblance she did carrie vnder feigned hew.
I chaunst to see her in her proper hew,
And dimmed sight with pale and deadly hew
And that dread Lyons looke her cast in deadly hew.
As ashes pale of hew and seeming ded;
Sans-foy his shield is hangd with bloudy hew:
Where she all day did hide her hated hew.
Both breathing vengeaunce, both of wrathfull hew:
He would them gazing blind, or turne to other hew.
For now three Moones haue cha[n]ged thrice their hew,
Were wont to riue steele plates, and helmets hew,
And this misseeming hew your manly looks doth marre?
And chaunge of hew great passion did bewray;
Till he recouered had his former hew:
With stony eyes, and hartlesse hollow hew,
Gan with new rage their shields to hew and cut;
But heauenly pourtraict of bright Angels hew,
Discerne the hew thereof. He neuer stood,
Of griesly hew, and fowle ill fauour'd sight;
And ouer them sad Horrour with grim hew,
The hew thereof: for vew of chearefull day
Yet was not that same her owne natiue hew,
And deadly hew, an armed corse did lye,
With so fresh hew vprising him to see,
Thousand times fairer then her mortall hew,
But that too oft she chaung'd her natiue hew:
Of swarth complexion, and of crabbed hew,
But the fift troupe most horrible of hew,
With grassie greene of delectable hew,
Of Death, and like him lookes in dreadfull hew,
But th'vpper halfe their hew retained still,
A trayle of yuie in his natiue hew:
But if in liuing colours, and right hew,
Which staines his snowy skin with hatefull hew:
So soone as Night had with her pallid hew
At last the fury past, to former hew
All suddeinly abasht she chaunged hew,
Her soueraigne bounty, and celestiall hew,
She heauenly borne, and of celestiall hew.
And soyle which did deforme their liuely hew;
And then of him are clad with other hew,
And all the fruitfull spawne of fishes hew
To change her hew, and sundry formes to don,
She was astonisht at her heauenly hew,
Which words when Paridell had heard, his hew
Her goodly personage and glorious hew,
Whenas the God to golden hew him selfe transfard.
As ashes pale of hew, and wingyheeld;
That now had chang'd her former wonted hew:
And shields did share, & mailes did rash, and helmes did hew.
To weete, two Ladies of most goodly hew,
Made her to change her hew, and hidden loue t'appeare.
Which being once withdrawne, most perfect hew
The heauenly pourtraict of bright Angels hew.
That was a Ruby of right perfect hew,
Before misfortune did his hew deface:
Of stature huge, and horrible of hew,
Who through the likenesse of my outward hew,
With nimble wings of gold and purple hew;
All decked in a robe of watchet hew,
That in short space his wonted chearefull hew
Withouten pitty of her goodly hew,
Ne of that goodly hew remayned ought,
As to haue robde you of that manly hew?
He much admired both his heart and hew,
Being returned to his former hew:
He brought forth that old hag of hellish hew,
For they were all, they say, of purple hew,
And with his huge great yron axe gan hew
Hung loose and loathsomely: Thereto her hew
At length breakes forth, and brode displayes his smyling hew.
And nought regarding her so goodly hew,
Wasting her goodly hew in heauie teares,
Her heart does quake, and deadly pallid hew
Of whom he makes such hauocke and such hew,
As if some miracle of heauenly hew
That twixt his pleasing tongue, and her faire hew,
(Saue onely Glorianaes heauenly hew
And pitty her sad plight, so chang'd from pleasaunt hew.
Faire Pastorella, whose sad mournefull hew
But askt againe, what ment that rufull hew;
And all that nere him came, did hew and slay,
Besides her countenaunce, and her likely hew,
And th'Images for all their goodly hew,
And fared like a feend, right horrible in hew.
That a large share it hewd out of the rest,
Fiue ioynts thereof he hewd, and but the stump him left.
And made such way, that hewd it quite in twaine;
He hewd, and lasht, and foynd, and thundred blowes,
He stroke, he soust, he foynd, he hewd, he lasht,
She hewd, she foynd, she lasht, she laid on euery side.
Which they now hackt & hewd, as if such vse they hated,
They hew'd their helmes, and plates asunder brake,
And helmets hewen deepe, shew marks of eithers might.
Hewen out of Adamant rocke with engines keene,
Whose hartstrings with keene steele nigh hewen be,
Of hewen stone the porch was fairely wrought,
Hewen vnderneath that Mount, that none him losen may.
And all the hewen stones thereof defaced,
Is wondrous strong, and hewen farre vnder ground
Whom then she does transforme to mo[n]strous hewes,
Which hewing quite a sunder, further way
Hewing and slashing at their idle shades;
Hewing, and slashing shields, and helmets bright,
And hewing off his head, [he] it presented
Like an huge caue, hewne out of rocky clift,
His onely daughter, and his onely heyre;
And him with her made of his kingdome heyre,
She Angel-like, the heyre of ancient kings
The danger hid, the place vnknowne and wilde,
And fro me hid: of whose most innocent death
Who all that while lay hid in secret shade:
And haue beene thrice hid vnderneath the ground,
And hid his face; through which his hollow eyne
Let nought be hid from me, that ought to be exprest.
But hid her visage, and her head downe bent,
For dread of soaring hauke her selfe hath hid,
I hid my selfe from it, as one affeard;
And the hid treasures in her sacred tombe,
And hid in darkenesse, that none could behold
The rest hid vnderneath, him more desirous made.
So hid in lockes and waues from lookers theft,
That hid no whit her alablaster skin,
Bene in his ashes raked vp, and hid,
Through the thicke woods, wherein he would haue hid
By her hid from the world, and from the skill
Downe in her lap she hid her face, and loudly shright.
Which in th'earthes hollow caues hath long bin hid,
Lay hid: thereof she countlesse summes did reare,
As faining to be hid from enuious eye;
But walkt each where, for feare of hid mischaunce,
The lines of life, from liuing knowledge hid.
And pyning anguish hid in gentle hart,
Lay hid in horrour of eternall night?
And all their sundry kinds, and all their hid abodes.
And shall see Stamford, though now homely hid,
And hid them selues in corners here and there;
And hid themselues in holes and bushes from his vew.
To change his shield with him, to be better hid.
Would haue the passion hid, and vp arose withall.
Had hid themselues, or taken further flight:
Her flesh for felnesse, which she inward hid:
And closely hid her selfe within the groue.
To some hid end to make more easie way,
To this attempt, to wreake his hid despight,
Shame would be hid. But whenas Enias
Were hidd in water, that I could not see,
That vnder it hidde hate and hollow guyle.
The antique rolles, which there lye hidden still,
Seemed in heart some hidden care she had,
The forward footing for an hidden shade:
Silly old man, that liues in hidden cell,
Who all this while with charmes and hidden artes,
Some secret ill, or hidden foe of his:
Shall I accuse the hidden cruell fate,
The hidden power of herbes, and might of Magicke spell?
The hidden cause of their captiuitie,
An hidden rocke escaped hath vnwares,
The further processe of her hidden griefe;
And fild her hidden caues with stormie yre,
Such helplesse harmes yts better hidden keepe,
From which I sprong, from me are hidden yit.
But told it flames, and hidden it does glow,
So creeping close, as Snake in hidden weedes,
Or in his wombe might lurke some hidden nest
Yet haue from wisest ages hidden beene:
Had him betidde, or hidden daunger did entrap.
And inly grieue, as doth an hidden moth
That hidden lyes vnwares him to surpryse?
Or with the hidden fire too inly warmd.
Of hellish Styx, which hidden vertue to it gaue.
T'assayle with open force or hidden guile,
And a whirlepoole of hidden ieopardy,
Into great Tethys bosome, where they hidden lye.
Worse is the daunger hidden, then descride.
Into his hidden net full easily doth fall.
Lay hidden in the bottome of the pot;
Vnwares the hidden hooke with baite I swallowed.
Were from him hidden, or vnknowne of yore.
More hidden are, then Sunne in cloudy vele;
Vnder thy mantle blacke there hidden lye,
Eftsoones out of her hidden caue she cald
And tell thy griefe, if any hidden lye;
Like a discolourd Snake, whose hidden snares
Vile treason and fowle falshood hidden were,
By wondrous skill, and many hidden wayes,
Made her to change her hew, and hidden loue t'appeare.
Sends forth the winds out of his hidden threasure,
For feare of harme, that might lie hidden there;
Cannot recount, nor tell their hidden race,
If ought lay hidden in his grieued thought,
At length found out, whereas she hidden lay
And wyder made the wound of th'hidden dart.
Whose hidden drift he could not well perceiue;
Can from th'immortall Gods ought hidden bee?
And roiall pompe, which there long hidden lay,
And hidden wayes, that scarse an hound by smell
And then came Daunger threatning hidden dread,
And the third time out of an hidden shade,
All hidden crimes, through all that realme he sent,
Where it in siluer bowre does hidden ly
She hidden was, and sought her so long, as him list.
Without suspect of ill or daungers hidden dred.
Sir Calepine himselfe away had hidden it.
Yet she much whiter, but the same did hide
Did spred so broad, that heauens light did hide,
And hide thy head. Therewith vpon his crest
There they alight, in hope themselues to hide
And long time hauing tand his tawney hide
Which vnderneath did hide his filthinesse,
Where she all day did hide her hated hew.
And let eternall night so sad [sight] fro me hide.
From liuing eyes her open shame to hide,
And hide the smoke, that did his fire display,
His harder hide would neither perce, nor bight,
Wherewith her heauenly beautie she did hide,
And sacred lampe in secret chamber hide,
To hide her shame and loathly filthinesse;
To hide his coward head from dying dreed.
So shakes off shame, ne thinks how erst she did her hide.
Into the hollow earth, them there to hide.
And these rich heapes of wealth doest hide apart
So huge a masse, and hide from heauens eye?
And Shame his vgly face did hide from liuing eye.
Yet with faire semblaunt sought to hide the breach,
Without or robe, or rag, to hide his shame.
That all the land they vnder them did hide;
Such as the Indians in their quiuers hide;
Whom to pursue, the Infant after hide,
Did vse to hide, and plaine apparaunce shonne:)
How euer finely she it faind to hide:
So may he long himselfe full easie hide:
And hellish arts from people she might hide,
As if they lay in wait, or else themselues did hide.
In lofty lookes to hide an humble mind,
Ne he twixt heauen and earth shall hide his hed,
He in a bush did hide his fearefull hed,
Till drouping Phoebus gan to hide his golden hed.
Who for to hide her fained sex the better,
To hide his falshood, then if it were trew:
Where they might hide their heads in quiet rest,
Yeeld such a sore, that doth her grieuance hide,
Thinking to hide the depth by troubling of the flood.
To hide her wound, that none might it perceiue:
To hide th'intent, which in my heart did lurke,
To hide the metall, which yet euery where
Vnto the shinie heauen in haste she hide,
And eke their dame halfe dead did hide her self for feare.
Doe hide themselues from her astonying looke,
To hide the blush which in her visage rose,
That I would hide, will needs, I see, be rad.
Cease thou bad newes-man, badly doest thou hide
But still right downe, and in her thought did hide
I will not seeke the same from you to hide,
To hide thy state from being vnderstood?
To hide the horrour, which did lurke behinde,
Or house to hide his head from heauens spight,
Creepes forth of dores, whilst darknes him doth hide,
Into their caues, their heads from death to hide,
And angry Ioue an hideous storme of raine
And rushed forth, hurling her hideous taile
That daunted with their forces hideous,
But they did seeme more foule and hideous,
A dreadfull Dragon with an hideous trayne,
With hideous horrour both together smight,
Ah heauens, that do this hideous act behold,
An hideous Geant horrible and hye,
His golden wings: his dreadfull hideous hed
Ne shame he thought to shunne so hideous might:
With which his hideous club aloft he dites,
With that they heard a roaring hideous sound,
But his most hideous head my toung to tell
His hideous tayle then hurled he about,
Of whose fowle deedes, too hideous to be told
To thinke, such hideous puissaunce on foot to beare.
And couer'd heauen with hideous dreriment,
With hideous strokes, and importable powre,
Of hideous Giants, and halfe beastly men,
Which that huge sonne of hideous Albion,
(O hideous hunger of dominion) hither came.
Whose hideous shapes were like to feends of hell,
And euermore their hideous Ordinance
Halfe in a maze with horror hideous,
An hideous roaring farre away they heard,
On th'other side an hideous Rocke is pight,
Eftsoones they saw an hideous hoast arrayd,
Ere long they heard an hideous bellowing
Now turned into figures hideous,
Whose hideous horror and sad trembling sound
It is an hideous hollow caue (they say)
Halfe of thy dayes doest lead in horrour hideous.
An hideous beast, of horrible aspect,
Which quaked vnder their so hideous masse,
From an huge Geaunt, that with hideous
Whose hideous tayle his left foot did enfold,
With that, an hideous storme of winde arose,
An hideous storme, is by the Northerne blast
The hideous Chaos keepes, their dreadfull dwelling is.
They felt, could once sustaine the hideous stowre,
And in his head an hideous wound imprest:
Of all the heard, meete with so hideous maine,
When all vnwares he felt an hideous sway
Ran forth in hast with hideous outcry,
The hideous noise of their huge strokes did heare,
An hideous Giant, dreadfull to behold,
Vnder the hanging of an hideous clieffe,
An hideous tempest seemed from below,
Like to an hideous storme, which nothing may empeach.
An hideous monster doth in darknesse lie,
An hideous monster, that doth it defend,
Horrible, hideous, and of hellish race,
Of stature huge and hideous he was,
On hideous strokes with most importune might,
So hideous is her shape, so huge her hed,
In hideous horrour and obscurity,
And eeke of person huge and hideous,
And therewith stroke at her so hideouslie,
And thundred strokes thereon so hideouslie,
So hideously vppon his armour bright,
And hides for shame. What wit of mortall wight
With smoake and sulphure hiding all the place,
For golden Phoebus now ymounted hie,
Now when Aldeboran was mounted hie
And fall away, it mounted was full hie,
At last the trumpets Triumph sound on hie,
Nigh to a castle builded strong and hie:
Or like that sacred hill, whose head full hie,
Then gan triumphant Trompets sound on hie,
But either hellish feends, or powres on hie:
But Guyon after him in haste did hie,
